system.name: pj
system.description: A POSIX-compliant terminal project manager framework that integrates with tmux and fzf to streamline project workflows.
keyFeatures: Project lifecycle management (create, open, archive, delete)
Tmux session integration for isolated project environments
Extensible with custom plugins and recipes
Minimal dependencies on standard Unix tools

external.name: sh
external.purpose: Primary shell interpreter for all PJ scripts; POSIX compliance is critical.
external.installation: Built-in on most Unix-like systems (e.g., `/bin/sh`). Often symlinked to Bash or Dash.

external.name: tmux
external.purpose: Terminal multiplexer for creating and managing persistent project sessions.

interfaces.name: tmux commands
interfaces.description: PJ uses tmux commands to create, attach to, and manage sessions/windows/panes.

methods.name: new-session
methods.parameters: `-d`: detached; `-s`: session name; `-c`: start directory; `-e`: environment variables.
methods.returnValue: Exits 0 on success, non-zero on failure. Creates a new tmux session.
methods.sideEffects: Changes tmux server state (new session created).

methods.name: has-session
methods.returnValue: Exits 0 if session exists, 1 if not.

methods.name: switch-client
methods.returnValue: Exits 0 on success. Switches client to specified session.

methods.name: attach-session
methods.returnValue: Exits 0 on success. Attaches client to specified session.

methods.name: send-keys
methods.parameters: `-t`: target pane; `<keys>`: keys to send; `<Enter>`: send Enter key.
methods.returnValue: Exits 0 on success. Sends key strokes to a pane.
methods.sideEffects: Modifies input buffer of a tmux pane.

external.name: fzf
external.purpose: General-purpose command-line fuzzy finder for interactive selection of projects.

interfaces.name: fzf command
interfaces.description: Used to filter and select items from stdin, outputting the selected item to stdout.

methods.name: fzf
methods.parameters: Options like `--border`, `--preview`, `--margin`, `--color`, `--with-nth`, `--delimiter` are used to configure appearance and parsing.
methods.returnValue: The selected line from stdin, or empty string if aborted. Exits 0 on selection, 130 on SIGINT (Ctrl+C), 1 on error.
methods.sideEffects: None directly, interacts with user input.

external.name: tree
external.purpose: Lists contents of directories in a tree-like format, used for fuzzy finder previews.

interfaces.name: tree command
interfaces.description: Outputs a tree representation of directory contents.

methods.name: tree
methods.parameters: `-L`: max display level; `-C`: colorized output; `--dirsfirst`: list directories before files.

external.name: awk
external.purpose: Pattern scanning and processing language, used for formatting output in utilities and help messages.

external.name: sed
external.purpose: Stream editor for filtering and transforming text, used for string manipulation.

external.name: grep
external.purpose: Text search utility, used for parsing configuration files and log output.

external.name: curl
external.purpose: Command-line tool for transferring data with URLs, used for downloading installation scripts and checking updates.

external.name: tar
external.purpose: Archiver utility, used for compressing and decompressing project archives.
external.version: Any stable version (GNU Tar recommended for .xz support)

external.name: cat
external.purpose: Concatenates files and prints on the standard output.

external.name: date
external.purpose: Prints or sets the system date and time.

external.name: read
external.purpose: Reads a line from standard input.

external.name: jq
external.purpose: Lightweight and flexible command-line JSON processor, used for parsing GitHub API responses during updates.

integration.environmentRequirements: PJ requires a POSIX-compliant shell (e.g., bash, dash, zsh in sh emulation mode, ksh) and a standard Unix-like operating system (Linux, macOS). It relies heavily on standard command-line utilities. User's `PATH` environment variable must include `~/.local/bin` for the `pj` executable to be found.

initializationPatterns.description: Initial installation and setup of PJ framework.
Bootstrapping PJ runtime environment within a shell session (handled internally by `~/.local/bin/pj`).

commonPitfalls.issue: PJ command not found after installation.
commonPitfalls.solution: Ensure `~/.local/bin` is in your shell's `PATH` environment variable. Add `export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"` to your shell's startup file (e.g., `~/.bashrc`, `~/.zshrc`) and restart your terminal or source the file.

commonPitfalls.issue: Custom plugins or recipes are not executable.
commonPitfalls.solution: Verify that custom scripts in `~/.config/pj/plugins/` or `~/.config/pj/plugins/recipes/` have execute permissions. Run `chmod +x <path_to_script>`.

commonPitfalls.issue: Errors related to missing external commands (e.g., `fzf: command not found`).
commonPitfalls.solution: Install the reported missing dependency using your operating system's package manager (e.g., `sudo apt install fzf` on Debian/Ubuntu, `brew install fzf` on macOS).

integration.lifecycleDependencies: PJ relies on a functional `tmux` server for session management. When `pj open` is executed, it either connects to an existing `tmux` server or starts a new one. Project-specific `.pj` or `.project` setup scripts are executed *after* the `tmux` session is initialized and the current working directory is set. Environment variables defined in `.env` files are loaded into the `tmux` session before any project setup script runs.

pj_open.useCase: To quickly open or switch to a project in a dedicated tmux session, potentially running project-specific setup scripts.
pj_open.parameters: Arguments: `refresh` (string, optional) - If present, regenerates the project list before fuzzy selection. `help` (string, optional) - Displays help message for `open` command.
pj_open.prerequisites: System must have `tmux`, `fzf`, and `tree` installed. Project path must be accessible.
pj_open.sideEffects: Creates a new tmux session if one doesn't exist for the project. May execute `.pj` or `.project` script within the session. May create/update `$PROJECTS_LIST` file.
pj_open.returnValue: None. Attaches user to a tmux session or exits on error/cancellation.
exceptions: ERROR_ILLEGAL_OP: If an invalid argument other than `refresh` or `help` is provided.
ERROR_UNKNOWN_PROJECT: If the selected project path is invalid or inaccessible during internal processing.
Shell errors: If `tmux` or `fzf` commands fail.

pj_new.useCase: To create a new project directory structure based on a predefined recipe or custom template.
pj_new.parameters: `recipe` (string, required) - The name of the project recipe to use (e.g., 'base', 'my-custom-recipe'). `project-name` (string, required) - The desired name for the new project directory. `-o` or `--overwrite` (flag, optional) - If set, allows the command to overwrite an existing project directory with the same name.
pj_new.prerequisites: Recipe file must exist and be executable. `$PROJECTS_PATH` must be writable.
pj_new.sideEffects: Creates a new directory structure under `$PROJECTS_PATH` named `<project-name>`. May overwrite existing data if `--overwrite` flag is used. Triggers `pj refresh` via post-hook.
pj_new.returnValue: None. Exits on error or upon successful project creation.
exceptions: ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS: If required arguments are missing.
ERROR_UNKNOWN_PLUGIN: If the specified recipe does not exist.
ERROR_UNKNOWN_PROJECT: If the project name is invalid or not provided.
ERROR_PROJECT_EXISTS: If a project with the same name already exists and `--overwrite` is not used.
Shell errors: If `mkdir` or recipe script commands fail.

pj_archive.useCase: To compress a project directory into a timestamped `.tar.xz` archive for backup or storage.
pj_archive.parameters: `project-name` (string, required) - The name of the project directory to be archived.
pj_archive.prerequisites: Project directory must exist under `$PROJECTS_PATH`. `tar` must be installed and support `.xz` compression. `$ARCHIVE_PATH` must be writable.
pj_archive.sideEffects: Creates a `.tar.xz` archive of the specified project in `$ARCHIVE_PATH`.
exceptions: ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS: If no project name is provided.
ERROR_ILLEGAL_OP: If project name is '.' or '..'.
ERROR_UNKNOWN_PROJECT: If the specified project does not exist.
Shell errors: If `tar` command fails (e.g., due to permissions, disk space).

pj_delete.useCase: To permanently remove a project directory from the file system, with a confirmation step.
pj_delete.parameters: `project-name` (string, required) - The name of the project directory to be deleted.
pj_delete.prerequisites: Project directory must exist under `$PROJECTS_PATH`. User must confirm deletion via interactive prompt.
pj_delete.sideEffects: Deletes the specified project directory and all its contents. (IRREVERSIBLE)
exceptions: ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS: If no project name is provided.
ERROR_ILLEGAL_OP: If project name is '.' or '..'.
ERROR_UNKNOWN_PROJECT: If the specified project does not exist.
Shell errors: If `rm -rf` command fails (e.g., due to permissions).

pj_list.useCase: To display a list of all project directories managed by PJ under `$PROJECTS_PATH`.
pj_list.parameters: `help` (string, optional) - Displays help message for `list` command.
pj_list.returnValue: Outputs a list of project names to standard output, one per line.
exceptions: Shell errors: If `ls` command fails (e.g., due to permissions).

pj_refresh.useCase: To regenerate PJ's internal list of known projects, typically after manual changes to project directories outside of PJ.
pj_refresh.parameters: `help` (string, optional) - Displays help message for `refresh` command.
pj_refresh.prerequisites: `$PROJECTS_LIST_GENERATOR` script must be present and executable, or default generator must be used. `$PROJECTS_LIST` file must be writable.
pj_refresh.sideEffects: Overwrites the content of `$PROJECTS_LIST` with the current list of project paths.
exceptions: Shell errors: If `_generate_list` or underlying commands (`find`, `echo`) fail.
ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS: If an invalid argument other than `help` is provided.

pj_update.useCase: To upgrade the PJ framework to its latest stable release.
pj_update.parameters: `help` (string, optional) - Displays help message for `update` command.
pj_update.prerequisites: Internet connectivity, `curl`, `jq` installed. Write permissions to `FRAMEWORK_PATH` and the `pj` executable.
pj_update.sideEffects: Downloads and installs latest PJ files, updates `pj` binary's version string.
exceptions: Shell errors: If `curl` or `jq` commands fail, or if installation script encounters issues. Network errors.
ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS: If an invalid argument other than `help` is provided.

pj_help.useCase: To display general help for the PJ framework or specific help for a given command.
pj_help.parameters: `command` (string, optional) - The name of a PJ command (e.g., `open`, `new`) for which to display specific help.
pj_help.returnValue: Outputs help text to standard output.

pj_example.useCase: Demonstrates a basic custom command within the PJ framework.
pj_example.parameters: `help` (string, optional) - Displays help message for `example` command.
exceptions: ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS: If an invalid argument other than `help` is provided.

run_command.useCase: Internal entry point for executing all PJ commands after initial flag parsing.
run_command.parameters: `command` (string, required) - The specific PJ command to execute (e.g., 'open', 'new'). `args` (string..., optional) - Any arguments to be passed to the command's `init` function.
run_command.prerequisites: Environment variables from `src/env.sh` and user `env.sh` must be sourced. Command module (`index.sh`) must exist and be executable.
run_command.sideEffects: Modifies internal framework variables (`FRAMEWORK_ARGUMENTS`). Executes pre/post hooks. Sources the target command's script.
run_command.returnValue: None. Execution flow is passed to the command's `init` function.
exceptions: ERROR_ILLEGAL_OP: If the command module cannot be found or executed.
Any errors from the executed command or its hooks.

parse_flag.useCase: Internal utility to identify and set global framework flags (`--silent`, `--overwrite`, `--help`, `--version`).
parse_flag.parameters: `argument` (string, required) - A command-line argument string to check if it's a known flag.
parse_flag.prerequisites: Global flag variables (`FLAG_SILENT`, `FLAG_OVERWRITE`, etc.) must be defined.
parse_flag.sideEffects: Sets global `FLAG_` environment variables if a flag is matched. May cause program exit for `--help` or `--version`.
parse_flag.returnValue: Returns 0 if `argument` is a flag, `NOT_A_FLAG` (997) otherwise.

setup.useCase: Sets up global project-related environment variables for a given project name.
setup.parameters: `project-name` (string, required) - The name of the project.
setup.prerequisites: `PROJECTS_PATH` and other related path variables must be set.

update_template.useCase: Updates placeholder values within a template file using `sed`.
update_template.parameters: `template-file` (string, required) - Path to the template file. `key:value` (string..., optional) - One or more `key:value` pairs to replace `{{key}}` placeholders with `value`.
update_template.prerequisites: Template file must exist. `sed` must be available.
exceptions: ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS: If no template file is specified.

fill_template.useCase: Interactively fills placeholder values in a template file by prompting the user for each `{{key}}`.
fill_template.parameters: `template-file` (string, required) - Path to the template file.
fill_template.prerequisites: Template file must exist. `grep`, `sed`, `read` must be available.
fill_template.sideEffects: Modifies the `template-file` in place based on user input.
exceptions: ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS: If no template file is specified.

extract_file.useCase: Copies a file from the PJ assets directory to a specified output path.
extract_file.parameters: `asset-name` (string, required) - Name of the asset file within `$ASSET_PATH`. `output-path` (string, required) - Destination path for the copied file.
extract_file.sideEffects: Copies file from source to destination.
exceptions: ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS: If asset name or output path is missing.

tabular.useCase: Formats a colon-separated string into a tabular output for help messages.
tabular.returnValue: Prints formatted string to standard output.

module_list.useCase: Generates a formatted list of available PJ commands (modules) with their summaries.
module_list.prerequisites: Module directories (`$FRAMEWORK_ROUTE`, `$CUSTOM_PLUGINS_PATH`) must be accessible. `grep`, `sed`, `awk` must be available.
module_list.returnValue: Prints a formatted list of command names and their summaries.

global_help.useCase: Displays the top-level help message for the PJ framework.

_generate_list.useCase: Generates or regenerates the list of project paths that `pj open` uses. Can be overridden by custom scripts.
_generate_list.prerequisites: Either `$PROJECTS_LIST_GENERATOR` must exist and be executable, or default behavior (listing `$HOME`) is used. `$PROJECTS_LIST` must be writable.
exceptions: Shell errors: If `find` or file operations fail.
ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS: If `$PROJECTS_LIST_GENERATOR` is not defined or accessible.

time_stamp.useCase: Generates a current time string in HH:MM:SS format.

repl.useCase: Internal utility to repeat a character a specified number of times.
repl.parameters: `char` (string, required) - The character to repeat. `count` (integer, required) - The number of times to repeat the character.

label.useCase: Formats a colored label for log and output messages (e.g., INFO, ERROR).
label.parameters: `color-function` (string, required) - Name of a color utility function (e.g., `bold_green`). `level-string` (string, required) - The label text (e.g., 'INFO', 'ERROR').
label.prerequisites: Color utility functions must be sourced.

log.useCase: Writes timestamped messages to the PJ log file.
log.parameters: `message` (string..., required) - The message content to log.
log.prerequisites: `FRAMEWORK_LOGS` environment variable must be set. `time_stamp` function must be available.

prompt.useCase: Formats and prints a stylized command-line prompt for user input.
prompt.parameters: `message` (string..., required) - The message to display as part of the prompt.
prompt.prerequisites: Color utility functions (`red`, `blue`) must be sourced.
prompt.returnValue: Prints formatted prompt to standard output.

question.useCase: Prompts the user for input with an optional default value.
question.parameters: `property` (string, required) - The question/property name to display. `default-value` (string, optional) - A default value to use if user provides no input.
question.returnValue: String: User input or default value.

inform.useCase: Prints an informational message to standard output.
inform.returnValue: Prints labeled message to standard output.

success.useCase: Prints a success message to standard output.
success.returnValue: Prints labeled message to standard output.

warn.useCase: Prints a warning message to standard output.
warn.returnValue: Prints labeled message to standard output.

trace.useCase: Prints a trace/debug message to standard output, typically used for progress indicators.
trace.returnValue: Prints labeled message to standard output.

debug.useCase: Prints a debug message to standard output. Can be silenced by `FLAG_SILENT`.
debug.prerequisites: `label` and `bold_blue` functions must be available. `FLAG_SILENT` variable checked.
debug.returnValue: Prints labeled message to standard output if not silent.

error.useCase: Prints an error message to standard output and logs it.
error.parameters: `message` (string, optional) - The error description. Defaults to 'an unexpected error occured!'. `error-code` (integer, optional) - The error code associated with the error. Defaults to `$ERROR`.
error.prerequisites: `log`, `label`, `bold_red` functions must be available. `FLAG_SILENT` is temporarily overridden.
error.sideEffects: Writes to log file. Sets `FLAG_SILENT` to 0 temporarily.
error.returnValue: Prints labeled error message to standard output.

panic.useCase: Prints an error message, logs it, and immediately exits the script with a specified error code.
panic.parameters: `message` (string, optional) - The error description. Defaults to 'an unexpected error occured!'. `error-code` (integer, optional) - The exit code. Defaults to `$ERROR`.
panic.prerequisites: `log`, `label`, `bold_red` functions must be available. `FLAG_SILENT` is temporarily overridden.
panic.sideEffects: Writes to log file. Exits the script. Sets `FLAG_SILENT` to 0 temporarily.

abort.useCase: Prints a critical error message and exits the script with a specified error code, often used for fatal installation/initialization errors.
abort.parameters: `message` (string, optional) - The error description. Defaults to 'an unexpected error occured!'. `error-code` (integer, optional) - The exit code. Defaults to `$ERROR`.
abort.sideEffects: Writes to log file. Exits the script.

notify.useCase: Prints a success or failure message based on the exit status of the previous command.
notify.parameters: `success-message` (string, required) - Message to display if previous command was successful. `failure-message` (string, required) - Message to display if previous command failed.
notify.returnValue: Prints success or error message to standard output.

banner.useCase: Displays the PJ ASCII art banner.
banner.prerequisites: Color utility functions (`yellow`, `blue`) must be sourced. `sleep` command is used for animation.
banner.returnValue: Prints ASCII art to standard output.

clear_line.useCase: Clears the current line in the terminal, used for animated loaders.
clear_line.prerequisites: Terminal must support ANSI escape codes.
clear_line.sideEffects: Modifies terminal cursor position and content.

load.useCase: Displays an animated loading spinner while a background process (PID) is running, then prints a final message.
load.parameters: `text` (string, required) - The text to display next to the spinner. `msg` (string, optional) - The message to display after loading finishes. `pid` (integer, required) - The process ID to monitor.
load.sideEffects: Outputs animated text to terminal. Clears lines. Prints final message.

show_version.useCase: Displays the PJ framework's version along with the banner.
show_version.prerequisites: `banner`, `load`, `bold_green` functions must be available. `FRAMEWORK_VERSION` must be set.
show_version.returnValue: Prints version information to standard output.

open_project_workflow.question: Which project should be opened or created?
open_project_workflow.logic: IF user_executes_"pj open" THEN IF `refresh` argument is present THEN `_generate_list` ELSE proceed_to_selection; THEN user_selects_project_via_fzf; THEN `_sessionize` project_path; ELSE display_help_or_error
open_project_workflow.validationMethod: Check `tmux ls` for active session. Verify current working directory in `tmux` pane.

create_new_project_workflow.question: How to create a new project with PJ?
create_new_project_workflow.logic: IF `pj new <recipe> <project-name>` is executed THEN IF project_exists AND `overwrite` flag is NOT set THEN `panic` with `ERROR_PROJECT_EXISTS` ELSE IF `recipe` is NOT found THEN `panic` with `ERROR_UNKNOWN_PLUGIN` ELSE execute_recipe_script(project_name); THEN run_command("refresh"); ELSE display_help_or_error
create_new_project_workflow.validationMethod: Check `ls $PROJECTS_PATH/<project-name>` for directory existence and content matching recipe.

flag_parsing_workflow.question: How are global flags handled?
flag_parsing_workflow.logic: IF `run_command` receives arguments THEN iterate_through_each_argument; THEN `parse_flag(argument)`; IF `parse_flag` returns 0 THEN argument_is_a_flag_and_handled ELSE argument_is_part_of_command_arguments; THEN filter_out_flags_from_`FRAMEWORK_ARGUMENTS`; ELSE continue_without_flags
flag_parsing_workflow.validationMethod: Check `FLAG_SILENT`, `FLAG_OVERWRITE` values after `run_command` with flags. Verify `FRAMEWORK_ARGUMENTS` does not contain flags.

open_project_fuzzy.description: Interactive selection of a project using fzf and opening it in a tmux session.

example.validation: A list of project paths is displayed, allowing fuzzy search and selection. A new tmux session is created for the selected project (e.g., 'my-project') if it doesn't exist, otherwise attaches to it.

create_project_from_recipe.description: Scaffolding a new project based on a predefined template script (recipe).

example.validation: Directory `$PROJECTS_PATH/my-new-project` exists and contains basic project files defined by the 'base' recipe (e.g., a `README.md`).
example.sideEffects: A new project directory is created. The project list is refreshed.

project_specific_setup.description: Automating project environment setup by executing a script (`.pj` or `.env`) within its tmux session.

example.code:
# In $PROJECT_PATH/.pj or $PROJECT_PATH/.project
#!/usr/bin/env sh

tmux neww -d -n workspace -t $session:2
tmux send-keys -t $session:1 "$EDITOR" Enter
example.validation: Upon `pj open` of the project, `tmux` session has specific windows/panes created or commands pre-filled as per the script. Environment variables from `.env` are set within the session.

confirm_and_delete.description: A safety pattern for destructive operations, requiring user to retype a confirmation string.

example.code:
pj delete my-risky-project
# (System prompts for confirmation keyword, e.g., 'my-risky-project-123')
example.validation: If correct keyword is entered, `$PROJECTS_PATH/my-risky-project` directory is removed. Otherwise, an 'incorrect input!' message is displayed, and the project remains.

command_lifecycle.description: The sequence of execution for any PJ command, including flag processing and hook execution.

example.code:
run_command "new" "base" "my-project" "--silent"

# Internal flow:
# 1. _remove_flags "new" "base" "my-project" "--silent" -> sets FLAG_SILENT=1, FRAMEWORK_ARGUMENTS="new base my-project"
# 2. _module_start "new" "base" "my-project"
# 3. _run_hook "new" pre_hook.sh "new" "base" "my-project"
# 4. Sources src/module/new/index.sh (calls init "base" "my-project")
# 5. On exit, _run_hook "new" post_hook.sh "new" "base" "my-project" is triggered (e.g., runs pj refresh)
example.validation: All flags are correctly parsed and applied. Pre-hooks execute before main command logic. Post-hooks execute after, regardless of main command success.

custom_project_generator.description: Overriding PJ's default project discovery mechanism to include projects from arbitrary file system locations.

example.code:
# ~/.config/pj/plugins/generator
#!/bin/sh

# Add projects from a specific client work directory
find "$HOME/work/client-xyz" -maxdepth 1 -type d -name "proj-*" >> "$PROJECTS_LIST"

# Also include any project directories directly in the home folder
ls -d "$HOME"/*/ | sed 's/\/$//' >> "$PROJECTS_LIST"
example.validation: After creating and making `~/.config/pj/plugins/generator` executable, running `pj open` or `pj refresh` will list projects from `$HOME/work/client-xyz` and `$HOME/*` directories.
example.sideEffects: `$PROJECTS_LIST` file is populated by the custom script.

animated_loading_indicator.description: Provides visual feedback for long-running operations by displaying a spinner and updating message.

example.code:
my_long_task & 
pid=$!
load "Processing data" "Data processed successfully" $pid
wait $pid
example.validation: A spinning animation appears next to 'Processing data'. Once `my_long_task` completes, the spinner disappears, and 'Data processed successfully' is printed.

status_based_feedback.description: Provides a success or failure message based on the exit status of the immediately preceding command.

example.code:
mkdir my_new_dir
notify "Directory created!" "Failed to create directory!"

# Output if successful:
#   SUCCESS  Directory created!

# Output if mkdir fails (e.g., directory already exists):
#   ERROR    Failed to create directory! (exit code 1)
example.validation: The `notify` function prints a green success message if `mkdir` exits with 0, or a red error message (including exit code) if `mkdir` exits non-zero.

basic_error_handling.description: Logs an error and prints it to the console, but does not necessarily exit the script immediately.

example.code:
if [ ! -d "/non/existent/path" ]; then
  error "Directory does not exist" "2"
fi

# Output:
#   ERROR    Directory does not exist
# (Script continues execution)
example.validation: An error message is displayed, and an entry is added to `$FRAMEWORK_LOGS`. The shell script proceeds with subsequent commands.

critical_error_exit.description: Prints an error, logs it, and forces script termination with a specific exit code for unrecoverable errors.

example.code:
if [ -z "$REQUIRED_VAR" ]; then
  panic "Required variable not set!" "$ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS"
fi

# Output:
#   ERROR    Required variable not set!
# (Script exits with status $ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS)
example.validation: An error message is displayed and logged. The shell script immediately terminates with the specified exit code.

installation_failure_exit.description: Specifically used during installation or critical setup steps to signal a fatal failure and exit.

example.code:
if ! _check_dependencies; then
  _abort "Missing critical dependencies!"
fi

# Output:
# [ Install failed ! ]
# (Script exits with status 27)
example.validation: A prominent 'Install failed!' message is displayed. The script terminates with exit code 27 (hardcoded for install failures).

ERROR.symptoms: Generic error message, unexpected behavior, script termination.
ERROR.properties: None, typically used as a default exit code.

scenarios.trigger: Any unhandled error where a specific error code isn't assigned.

ERROR.diagnosis: Review logs for context. Check preceding commands for non-zero exit codes.
ERROR.resolution: Identify the specific cause of the failure using debug logging. Add more specific error handling.
ERROR.prevention: Implement robust checks for preconditions and post-conditions.
ERROR.propagationBehavior: Bubbles up to the caller unless explicitly caught (e.g., using `trap` or `||` logic).

ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS.symptoms: Command-line tool complains about missing arguments or unknown flags. Help message is often displayed.

scenarios.trigger: Invoking `pj new` without specifying a recipe or project name.
scenarios.reason: Missing required arguments for the command.

scenarios.trigger: Invoking `pj archive` or `pj delete` without a project name.
scenarios.reason: Action cannot be performed without a target.

ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS.diagnosis: Read the command's help output (`pj <command> help`) to understand expected arguments.
ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS.resolution: Provide all required arguments and use correct flags.
ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS.handlingPatterns: Implement validation checks for arguments at the start of command `init` functions.
ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS.propagationBehavior: Typically caught at the command's `parse_args` function and results in `panic`.

ERROR_PROJECT_EXISTS.symptoms: Attempting to create a new project, but a directory with the same name already exists in `$PROJECTS_PATH`.

scenarios.trigger: Running `pj new my-project` when `~/projects/my-project` already exists.
scenarios.reason: Project creation conflict without explicit overwrite permission.

ERROR_PROJECT_EXISTS.diagnosis: Verify if the project indeed exists at the specified path. Check for typos in project name.
ERROR_PROJECT_EXISTS.resolution: Use a different project name, or if intentional, use the `--overwrite` flag: `pj new <recipe> <project-name> --overwrite`.
ERROR_PROJECT_EXISTS.prevention: Check for existence before creation, or always use `--overwrite` if desired.
ERROR_PROJECT_EXISTS.propagationBehavior: Causes a `panic` in the `pj new` command.

ERROR_PROJECT_NOT_EXISTS.symptoms: Attempting to perform an operation (archive, delete) on a project that does not exist.
ERROR_PROJECT_NOT_EXISTS.diagnosis: Verify the exact project name and its location under `$PROJECTS_PATH`.
ERROR_PROJECT_NOT_EXISTS.resolution: Provide the correct project name or ensure the project directory actually exists.
ERROR_PROJECT_NOT_EXISTS.prevention: Use `pj list` to confirm project names before operations.
ERROR_PROJECT_NOT_EXISTS.handlingPatterns: Handled internally by `archive` and `delete` command's `parse_args` functions.
ERROR_PROJECT_NOT_EXISTS.propagationBehavior: Causes a `panic` in the respective command.

ERROR_UNKNOWN_PLUGIN.symptoms: The specified plugin (e.g., recipe for `pj new`) could not be found.

scenarios.reason: The recipe file `custom-flask-app` does not exist in `$RECIPES_PATH` or `$CUSTOM_RECIPES_PATH`.

ERROR_UNKNOWN_PLUGIN.diagnosis: Verify the recipe name is correct. Check if the recipe file exists in `~/.config/pj/plugins/recipes/` or core `src/plugins/recipes/`.
ERROR_UNKNOWN_PLUGIN.resolution: Correct the recipe name, or create the custom recipe if intended.
ERROR_UNKNOWN_PLUGIN.prevention: Use `pj new help` to see available recipes, or verify custom recipe paths.
ERROR_UNKNOWN_PLUGIN.propagationBehavior: Causes a `panic` in the `pj new` command.

ERROR_UNKNOWN_FLAG.symptoms: An unrecognized flag is passed to a PJ command.

scenarios.trigger: Passing an invalid flag like `--invalid-flag` to any PJ command.
scenarios.reason: The argument is not a defined global flag or command-specific option.

ERROR_UNKNOWN_FLAG.diagnosis: Check the available flags for the command (`pj <command> help`) or global flags (`pj help`).
ERROR_UNKNOWN_FLAG.resolution: Remove the unknown flag or replace it with a valid one.
ERROR_UNKNOWN_FLAG.prevention: Refer to documentation for valid flags.
ERROR_UNKNOWN_FLAG.propagationBehavior: Typically does not cause a `panic` directly, but `_remove_flags` will filter it out, and the command might then report `ERROR_INVALID_OPTIONS` if a required argument is missing due to the flag being mistaken for one.

ERROR_ILLEGAL_OP.symptoms: An operation is attempted that is not permitted or is contextually invalid (e.g., deleting parent directories).

scenarios.trigger: Attempting to `delete` or `archive` the current directory or parent directory using '.' or '..'.
scenarios.reason: Security/safety measure to prevent accidental deletion of critical paths.

scenarios.trigger: PJ cannot find or execute a command module's `index.sh` script.
scenarios.reason: Indicates a framework internal issue or a truly non-existent command.

ERROR_ILLEGAL_OP.diagnosis: Review the specific command's `parse_args` function and the general `_module_start` logic.
ERROR_ILLEGAL_OP.resolution: Avoid problematic arguments (e.g., use specific project names). Reinstall PJ if core modules are missing/corrupted.
ERROR_ILLEGAL_OP.handlingPatterns: Handled in command `parse_args` or `_module_start` leading to `panic`.
ERROR_ILLEGAL_OP.propagationBehavior: Causes a `panic` for critical unrecoverable operations.

ERROR_UNKNOWN_PROJECT.symptoms: The project specified for an operation (e.g., `archive`, `delete`, `open`) cannot be located by PJ.

scenarios.trigger: Trying to archive a project that was manually deleted.
scenarios.reason: The project directory does not exist at `$PROJECTS_PATH/<project-name>`.

ERROR_UNKNOWN_PROJECT.diagnosis: Check for typos in the project name. Verify the project's physical location and `PROJECTS_PATH` configuration.
ERROR_UNKNOWN_PROJECT.resolution: Correct the project name, or ensure the project exists in the expected location.
ERROR_UNKNOWN_PROJECT.prevention: Use `pj list` to verify project names before critical operations.
ERROR_UNKNOWN_PROJECT.handlingPatterns: Handled in `parse_args` functions of relevant commands (archive, delete, open).
ERROR_UNKNOWN_PROJECT.propagationBehavior: Causes a `panic` in the respective command.

NOT_A_FLAG.symptoms: Internal flag parsing mechanism indicating that a given argument is not recognized as a global flag.

scenarios.trigger: A non-flag argument is passed to `parse_flag`.
scenarios.reason: This is expected behavior when processing regular command arguments.

NOT_A_FLAG.diagnosis: Not typically an 'error' for the end-user, but an internal signal.
NOT_A_FLAG.handlingPatterns: Used by `_remove_flags` to distinguish between flags and command arguments.
NOT_A_FLAG.propagationBehavior: Returns to caller (`_remove_flags`) to decide further action.
